content.statement: proc-005-subclavian-exposure is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Procedures that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding proc-005-subclavian-exposure helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of proc-005-subclavian-exposure include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of proc-005-subclavian-exposure.

definitions_glossary.anterior_scalene: Muscle from C3-C6 to first rib, subclavian artery runs behind it
definitions_glossary.phrenic_nerve: Nerve to diaphragm, runs on anterior surface of anterior scalene
definitions_glossary.brachial_plexus: Network of nerves to upper extremity, posterior and superior to subclavian artery
definitions_glossary.thoracic_duct: Main lymphatic duct, empties at left venous angle (jugular-subclavian junction)
definitions_glossary.vertebral_artery: First branch of subclavian, runs posteriorly into transverse foramina

indications: Subclavian artery stenosis/occlusion with subclavian steal
contraindications: Prior clavicular fracture with extensive scarring (consider alternative approach)

technique.positioning: Supine, head turned away, shoulder roll, ipsilateral arm at side

supraclavicular_approach.incision: Transverse, 1-2cm above clavicle, from SCM to trapezius
layers: Clavicular head of SCM (divide if needed)
Scalene fat pad (divide carefully - lymphatics, transverse cervical vessels)
Anterior scalene muscle (after protecting phrenic nerve)

key_structures.phrenic_nerve: On anterior scalene - MUST identify before dividing muscle
key_structures.transverse_cervical_artery: May cross field, divide if needed
key_structures.thoracic_duct: Left side, at venous angle - ligate if injured

steps: Identify and retract external jugular vein
Divide clavicular head of SCM if needed
Identify phrenic nerve on anterior scalene
Identify vertebral artery origin if needed

infraclavicular_approach.use: For axillary artery access, bypass inflow, trauma

complications.manifestation: Diaphragm paralysis, dyspnea, elevated hemidiaphragm on CXR
complications.prevention: Always identify nerve ON anterior scalene before dividing muscle
complications.management: Usually traction injury recovers; permanent injury may need diaphragm plication

complications.prevention: Careful dissection at left venous angle, ligate lymphatics
complications.management: Ligate if identified; chylothorax needs chest tube, dietary modification, possible reoperation
Usually traction injury recovers over months

complications.prevention: Identify vein early, control before artery

definition.@value: Surgical exposure of the subclavian artery through supraclavicular or infraclavicular approach for vascular procedures

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Describe the anatomy of the subclavian artery and thoracic outlet
Perform supraclavicular exposure of the subclavian artery
Identify and protect the phrenic nerve during anterior scalenectomy
Recognize and manage thoracic duct injury
clinical_pearls: The phrenic nerve runs ON the anterior scalene - find it before dividing the muscle
On the left side, always be aware of the thoracic duct at the venous angle
The subclavian artery is BEHIND the anterior scalene, not in front of it
For more proximal control, you may need to resect the medial clavicle or do a sternotomy
The vertebral artery is the first branch - look posteriorly to find it

medicalCode.description: Inspection of subclavian artery, open approach
